div.p: Greetings. You, indeed (reverend father in Christ), are too generous in writing amidst your many occupations; therefore, there was clearly no need for an apology to me. I give you immortal thanks, for you share everything; however, I could not return your writings now, because the messenger brought them at an inopportune time, but I will send them at the next market or more timely, if there are those to whom I can conveniently give them. I have nothing with which to reward you, except that I send the history of Gr√ºnbach, just as it was written to our consuls as certain through merchants, do not [re]send it." I have no doubt about its authenticity. I will remember your teachings, and I would have been briefer otherwise; but I have not read anything in Latin authors for a long time and I see now how unprepared I am, and I am displeased with myself; yet I pray to the Lord, who is present with me. One thing troubles me, where it might be printed, and now I do not have time to write to Mr. Oporinus. Farewell, reverend father in Christ.
In Chur, most hastily, in the year 1563, on the calends of November.

It is possible to gather many absurd interpretations of scripture from the decrees themselves and all papal law, such as that concerning holy water (for the consequences are also included here); therefore, I will not mention anything except what is confessed, do not doubt, etc.
To the most esteemed Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and father in Christ, to be eternally honored. In Zurich.
